intro: Silene vulgaris subsp. suffrutescens, commonly known as the redstem mouse-ear, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring succulent, often reddish stems and small, spoon-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of pink to purple flowers in late spring to early summer, which are arranged in racemes. It thrives in moist, calcareous soils and is often found in meadows, grasslands, and woodland edges. Its botanical features make it a characteristic species of the Silene genus, known for its showy inflorescences and ecological importance in supporting pollinators.
